number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												I really enjoyed this game, the puzzles were tough and made me scratch my head a few times. The concept is quite original and does require heavy thinking, especially when the game throws you a puzzle that requires all 4 dimensions to complete the puzzle.John de Lancie is great in this game too, he voices your uncle who is a scientist who makes wonderful gadgets and gismos, especially the glove you wear all the way through your journey. (not really a spoiler since it's told in the trailers and start of the game)The music isn't half bad either! Worth picking up in my opinion.However, nothing is perfect... let's get to the downsides, and this is a spoiler on the ending... in a spoiler free way though, I'll just say the ending sucks. All you get is a 30 second clip telling you that your character has been sent to a pocket dimension that your uncle was trapped in this entire time, while your uncle then gets out and tries to fix a problem that he helped you cause because he lost his memory and this problem is going to effect the entire planet. Then it rolls the credits.You may think that sounds awesome but it's explained in 30 seconds, and if you think that's enough for an awesome cutscene explaining that, you're wrong since the cutscenes in this game are set up exactly like the main menus, so you just see a drawing of the house fall into the ocean in an innocent cartoon-y fashion and then it shows the whole planet change colour repeatedly. That's it. No awesome looking climax like in Portal and Half-Life 2.It's a real shame this game had no better cutscene since the game was building the ending to be a nice sparkly bow to a great game, but it didn't which is a real shame since the game is worth it at full price but the ending made me feel like I wasted my time and that everything I did in the game was really for nothing. If the game was designed to be a series of tests that didn't have a narrative or story, then I wouldn't mind it but because it was building up this story, the ending felt very lazy and tacked on to make you interested into buying a sequel that we may never get (and unlikely will get).To wrap it up: The game is worth the full price, but the ending didn't make the game feel worth the journey (even though it is worth playing) and doesn't make me feel interested in buying the DLC. Oh, and the collectible items are really well hidden.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2012
												Remember all those idiots who kept saying "THE CAKE IS A LIE XD" because they played Portal once on their MacBooks in Starbucks and thought it was soooo nerdy?This is this Quantum Conundrum's demographic. Reddit-jokes,♥♥♥♥♥♥puns and "US SCIENTISTS HUH" jokes are all beneath the shell of this 5 hour game.Putting♥♥♥♥♥♥jokes & pandering to a certain demographic aside, QC is a fairly entertaining game. The artstyle & graphics are beautifully crafted and are Pixar-like in their appearance (though, baffably, there's no in-game AA option) and the gameplay remains solid throughout. Whilst QC is billed as a puzzler, levels have a fair amount of platforming thrown in as well to mixed results.The puzzles themselves are consistently easy throughout, I only found myself stuck on two occasions, with the narrator often throwing hints at you moments after you've entered the level. 4/10. It's too expensive for what it is. (Not as good as Portal XDD)

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2012
												Man, I honestly wanted to enjoy this game a lot more than I did but the number of things taken directly from Portal and then executed terribly was surprising.Some points:- The GlaDOS/Chell relationship is awkward and inappropriate when it's an Uncle ripping on his 10-year-old nephew/only means of rescue.- Connecting buttons/switches to doors with light-up lines is a good idea when the lines actually lead your eye somehow and aren't just haphazardly placed everywhere.- Exposing the "outside" of the “test-chambers” as the game progressed was necessary why?- You even did the part where the player falls down a giant elevator shaft to the heart of the facility? Seriously?- The end credits song was unbearable. Just terrible.That being said; I loved the clever book titles and neat paintings. There were also some really neat levels, and the general mechanics were very interesting. These things deserved much more than an awkward and poorly written first-person platformer.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I've just completed this game and I can't recommend it at all. This abomination of a game disguises itself with the Day of the Tentacle graphics, but is really an exercise in frustration. The basis of this game, the physics engine, is highly unreliable. Nearly every advanced procedure becomes a gamble. The checkpoint (which is a bad system to start with) saves neither your level time nor your dimension change count. This means: Every level (up to five minutes with ~50 required changes and REALLY tough time challenges) has to be done in one go to get the achievements. You'll waste a insane amount of time. One of the worst "gaming" experiences of my life.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.P.S.: Believe it or not. The DLC's are even worse. You'll just want to punch the devs in the face, really really hard....

content:
Posted: January 4
												This game is pretty good. There are a lot of puzzles to get through. There are four different "dimensions"; light-weight, heavy-weight, time slow-down, and inverse gravity. All four mechanics make for some interesting puzzles. The game is well-paced. It doesn't throw too much at you at once. It gradually builds you up.Professor Fitz Quadwrangle's mansion expresses a goofier side to science compared to the more sinister side to science that is Aperture Science.What grabbed my attention with this game was that it had Kim Swift as director, and I know her to have worked on the Portal series. Glad I bought this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Quantum Conundrum is one of the many examples of a good idea with poor execution. It has an idea that works, but the puzzles feel like they don't use the mechanics to it's full potential. My other main problem is the platforming. I've rarely seen good platforming in a Portal style physics game, and this game is no exception. Trying to land from point A to point B is an absolute nightmare with a first-person view! As for things I liked, the obvious one is John De Lancie as the narrator. His preformance is absolutely phenomenal and had me laughing through out my playthrough! I also love the visuals in the game! It's a nice bright cartoonish art style that is absolutely great to look at! My favorite thing about the visuals is how stuff like paintings, safes, etc. change depending on what dimension you're in! But overall, the game was mediocre at best, and got quite boring after only 40 minutes of playing. (And I also ♥♥♥♥ing hate Ike)

content:
Posted: September 11, 2012
												This is an okay first person platformer/puzzler. If you don't mind horrible, horrible puns and you're in the mood for interesting brain teasers Portal-style, this will keep you entertained for a little bit. The puzzles are mostly very simple - you're not going to find almost anything that will stump you, but from time to time you'll see an ingenious use of one or two physical mechanics related to your powers. At $20, this game pretty much lived up to its expectations for the price, but didn't surpass them. The story that drives you forward is silly-dumb and will make you wish for a more interesting plot, but it's mostly ignorable. Get this only if you miss FPS puzzle games and you don't want to play Portal again. 2 out of 5 foxes.

												I will not mention Portal in this review. Ops. Well, obviously this will rightfully compared to Portal and it's obviously inferior.The gameplay is fine - although unlike Portal, there's a lot of platforming and precision jumping/timing in it - and the design of some of the puzzles is awesome, but in every other aspect the game falls short. Especially the comedy aspect. It's just not a funny game, and seeing it try to be funny constantly while not being so is kind of annoying.So all said, I recommend this game only to fans of this specific genre. Everyone else, go play Portal. And Portal 2. And Anti-chamber, probably.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Cool, fun, quirky, like a Saturday morning Disney cartoon version of Portal. So why the negative review? Because the ending is pretty lackluster. So much so that it ruins the game for me. That is to say, however, as soon as a sequel comes out for this game that perhaps will more adequately tie up the story - get this game. The physics puzzles are very fun and can go from pathetically easy to mindbendingly difficult. I noticed that different people got held up by different puzzles, and many puzzles had more than 1 solution (though only one solution would be the easiest to execute). The characters of your crazy uncle and his extradimensional friend IKE are engaging and interesting, though not really unique. The house itself also has a character, communicated via the paintings found hanging around the grounds. It was a nice touch by the studio to have the paintings change according to which dimension you're in. A fun game for kids and adults alike, as long as you don't mind the ending being a real let-down. Hopefully a sequel will let me change the recommendation in the future.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												"I Hope You Enjoy Jumping Puzzles: The Game"This game is basically just a poorly-executed version of Portal devoid of the personality that added so much to that game's exceptional concept. The writing tries really hard to be funny and charming, but fails. The gameplay is pretty mediocre. The story makes no sense, and the environments are very same-ish and repetitive. If you absolutely have to have a physics-based puzzler and you've already played both Portal games, maybe this will satisfy you briefly (it has three or four decent puzzles). But it really, really isn't worth more than 5 bucks.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2013
												♥♥♥♥ this♥♥♥♥♥♥If I could downvote this game on Steam I would.  Figuring out the puzzles is easy.  Pulling off the complex timing and repetitive reflex manuvers needed to solve them is maddening.  Being forced to restart from the beginning of a puzzle because of one mistake is the work of the devil.The art assests and level design are the very definition off cookie-cutter layouts, and the music is as bland as it is forgettable.  John De Lancie phones this one in, but he can't take all the blame as the writing is as witless and dry as he portrays it to be.I've actualy encountered game halting bugs while playing, where the game fails to keep track of objects being destroyed through the various dimensional shifts causing me to have to reload certain sections of the game in order to retry them.I can't even recommend this game for kids as death is a constant factor in the game, which is handled poorly with one-liner throw-aways telling you of how bland and stale life is.  Add to the fact that some zones that appear to be safe are infact instant death only makes this situation worse.  In one area you can walk on metal plating and in another area it will kill you without rhyme nor reason.If there was one word to describe this game, it would be "Bland."  What made this game so annoying was that I was actually trying to enjoy it, but at almost every turn the crappy gameplay would just get in the way and punish me with death for a mis-step or force me to start an entire room over for a single mis-click.I will attest to being a masocist for challenging games, but there was no hint of a reward that would make me want to pursue playing this game further.  I can easily forgive bad gameplay if there was good writing, music or art to back it up  But this game has none of those things going for it.One afterword:  This game was designed for consoles in mind and it shows.  If that bothers you, well that's even more of a reason NOT to play it.

content:
Posted: April 1
												TLDR: Seems totally reasonable if you play in bounds. Punishes you for breaking the rules.As some of the negative reviews have said, maybe this game just wasn't for me. I'm sure if you play it the way the designers intended, you'd have a great time with it. I don't want to dissuade anyone who wants a nice puzzle game with well done art, which you play while Q from Star Trek makes vague jabs at you from his intercom. If that is your bag, then this game is for you.That said, I prefer treading on the edges of what game designers want you to do (I used to be QA for a game company and it never left my system I guess). I didn't make it to far into the game before it punished me for breaking a puzzle. I'd managed to sneak an extra safe into one of the levels from a previous level. I was hoping for an achievemnt, I would've accepted just solving the puzzle without jumping through all the hoops the level wanted me to, but instead, it just magically vaporized my safe when I took it to the side of the room where safes weren't allowed. As far as I could tell this wasn't the designers not accounting for what I did (which is fine), it was them accounting for what I did and deciding it still wasn't allowed. This bothered me greatly.I hope to still finish the game at some point, but for the time being it has left a bad taste in my mouth, and I wanted to warn anyone who picked this up looking for a game that rewards ingenuity outside of the original designers plans.  Again, if that's not you, this is (probably, I haven't finished it yet) a great game.

												This game is getting unfairly and pretty unfavorably compared to the Portal series by most video game review sites. I understand why this is happening since Kim Swift designed both games. But I really liked the two Portal games, and I also think QC is an extremely solid puzzle/platformer. I'm about 60% of the way through it, and I plan on purchasing both DLC/expansion packs as well!

Posted: July 24, 2012
												This is a pleasant puzzle game, like a Saturday Morning cartoon version of Portal. Please take note that it's quite short (finished the story in 7 hours, give or take time being baffled by a room), but the light-hearted sardonically humorous dialogue and art makes up for it.ALSO, if you are a fan of the vocal stylings of John de Lancie ( voice of Q and Discord), you will adore being his nephew. Hopping over unsafe lasers and dodging falling safes while listening to your new inventor uncle advise and patronize you is a most enjoyable mind-testing experience. Definitely buy it if you've got spare cash for a few hours of wholesome fun!

Posted: March 11
												I have not played this game much, but I love the voice acting (John de Lancie as the uncle/narrator), the storyline, and the game mechanics.So why haven't I finished the game or even played more than 44 minutes total?Because I get seriously motion sick.  I've turned down the mouse sensitivity enough to be able to play more than two minutes, but around fifteen minutes I start turning green.  Ugh.So I recommend this game to people who love comedic puzzles, with the caveat that you need to not be sensitive to mouse movement.

												You control time, weight and gravity to solve puzzles. Timeruns, least dimension shifts and collectibles feed the replayability.It's a pretty good game which should have concentrated a bit more on the puzzles instead of jumping and sofa rides.For those who need a numbered rating: It's a solid 85.

Posted: June 22, 2012
												Quantum Conundrum is a suprisingly unique puzzle game.  The puzzles are well made and fairly easy to solve, though they're substantially harder if you're trying to do the speed/min-shift runs. The art style works extremely well for the game.  The environment, including the many paintings, changes when shifting between dimensions, which is a very cool effect.  Quantum Conundrum is narrated by John de Lancie, and he voices your whimsicle, mad-scientist uncle perfectly.  The main game lasted me about 11 hours, and it comes highly recommended as the best puzzle game I've played since Portal 2.

Posted: June 25, 2012
												If you liked Potal and want more physics puzzle solving with great humour this is the game for you. cute visuals (feels like TF2) excellent amount of attention to detail, great voice acting and mind massaging puzzles. will make you shout EUREKA!  when you figure them out.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although the puzzles were sometimes clever, they were also disappointingly obvious most of the time and occasionally frustrating (see: first person platforming). It is often compared to Portal, but the comparison really only holds up to 1) It's a first person puzzle platformer and 2) the objective is to solve the room puzzle to advance. However, if you like the Portal genre, you'll get some satisfaction out of this.The environmental effects when you change dimensions are very well done and were the highlight of the game for me. While I enjoyed my time with it, I wouldn't mind seeing a sequel to flesh out the true potential of this franchise.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												An interesting 1st person puzzle platformer, in which the main mechanic consists in switching between 4 dimensions which affect your surroundings. For example: you can make objects lighter to transport them/throw them, make them heavier to break through glass or indestructible.I recommend it simply for the puzzles and the satisfaction it gives to complete a section when you've discovered an entirely new mechanic a dimension proposes, just by yourself. Honestly, there's a lot more into play than in Portal 1 and almost as much as Portal 2, and if you liked those two games, there's a lot of content to entertain you for a while in this game.However, I believe this game has a major flaw: its ending. No spoilers will be given here, but honestly, there is a great, inmensely great build-up while progressing through the final stages of the game. I was genuinely curious as to what was going to happen in the very last puzzle, and started imagining what it could be; but... Nothing. A rather abrupt ending, virtually no final puzzle, and... in retrospect, the puzzles right before the ending weren't even that much of a challenge either. I would have expected their difficulty/completxity to be something much greater, but... meh. I was really disappointed. And I mean, really, disappointed.Nonetheless, it's still a good game, and I really recommend it for those who want to enjoy the challenge and the gimmicks that this game can offer.

Posted: June 21, 2012
												As of this writing, I'm only ~25% in, but I honestly feel that's enough to write a recommendation for this.Think Portal, but without Thinking With Portals and instead thinking with Interdimensional Travel. Without a psychopathic AI nagging you, there's a potentially psychopathic family member, voiced by none other than John De Lancie, who provides just as much amusement as GLaDOS does.Drawing comparisons between this and Portal is pretty much the best way to describe it. It's a puzzler with moving things around and physics based puzzles that relate to the current properties of a material. Want something heavy? Lightweight? In slow motion? There's a dimension to solve that puzzle there.I'm playing with slightly bad framerate so the jumps are a little trickier for me, but it's something ignorable to the rest of the gameplay.Brilliant, and I strongly recommend you put down anything nonimportant / nonessential and buy this and play - right now.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Rating: 7/10Yes, this game is made by the lead developer of Portal 1/2, but it's not Portal 3. First of all, a significant portion of the game does not involve portals of any kind, but does involve a chuck of simmilar and more difficult puzzles. Also, it's sillier and targeted toward a younger audience. You can tell because when you die, there are life messages, and all of them are talking to younger kids.Overall, if you've played Portal 1/2 and enjoyed it, you'll enjoy this game. If you don't like first-person puzzle games with shooter mechanics, you won't like this game.

Posted: July 13, 2012
												This game feels familiar... it feels like Portal!  Kim Swift was lead designer, and it shows.  Sure, it doesn't have the writing of Portal... but that bar is so high.They really poured a lot of love into this game.  Little things aren't necessary to the gameplay but enhance the setting and put a smile on my face.  Paintings change according to the dimension -- go Fluffy and everything is pink and soft, maybe wearing a bunny suit... go Heavy and everyone wears leather and spikes.  Quite silly!  It's also fun to hear John de Lancie's voice.The whole game has a 'relaxed' feel... I've been pacing myself, playing a level or two a day, and it feels right.  Puzzles are straightforward so far; kind of a slow start, but this makes it accessible to people who haven't played Portal.  It's inexpensive, very family-friendly, and is the sort of thing I'd be glad to recommend to everyone from my 8-year-old cousins to my 30 year old friends.  There aren't many games out there that can boast that!

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although the puzzles were sometimes clever, they were also disappointingly obvious most of the time and occasionally frustrating (see: first person platforming). It is often compared to Portal, but the comparison really only holds up to 1) It's a first person puzzle platformer and 2) the objective is to solve the room puzzle to advance. However, if you like the Portal genre, you'll get some satisfaction out of this.The environmental effects when you change dimensions are very well done and were the highlight of the game for me. While I enjoyed my time with it, I wouldn't mind seeing a sequel to flesh out the true potential of this franchise.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												I bought this hoping for an experience similar to Portal. 9 hours and beaten, but it was cheap. It's a good game, but it has a major problem: John de Lancie (the PC's uncle) NEVER shuts up. He's annoying enough when he's not giving away the key to every puzzle you come across. I really started to loathe the character while playing this game. I guess the devs figured that they'd take as much advantage of the celebrity factor as possible, but the result is a deeply negative impact on what makes this game fun: figuring out the puzzles for yourself. They should have just asked GlaDOS.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												If Portal and Portal 2 are A grade movies, then Quantum is a solid B-.Quantum offers a spin on first-person puzzles being that it is a game based on different dimensions, and how you use them to complete the objective. The dimensions come from a glove you wear in the game, and are activated on-cue through keyboard bindings. The four dimensions are:1. "Fluffy" - Makes it so you can lift and throw what would normally be too heavy to handle items.2. "Heavy" - Makes items that would be considered "light" to instead have their mass increased (weigh more in non-scientific terms)3. "Slow" - Basically slow-mo.4. "Reverse Gravity" - As it says, items float to the ceiling when activated.The main story revolves around you, portrayed as a young nephew, trying to find his Uncle who is in an unknown location and needs help rescuing. How is it in comparison to a game like Portal?Quantum is missing the "charm" that Portal (specifically 2) has. The characters are not as unique or likeable. For example, isntead of Wheatley and GLaDOs, you get a furry animal named Ike and your "crazy scientist" uncle. There are no companion cubes, instead they are replaced with cartoon-like safes. The setting is bland; a mansion. And while you go through the puzzles, your uncle keeps chiming in with one-liners you would hear from a high school math teacher.Don't get me wrong. It may sound like I hate Quantum-quite the opposite. It is a very solid game with good mechanics and physics-based puzzles. However, the magic of the game just is not there. Many of the puzzles rely on timing and reflexes rather than thought and careful design. The story is not a life-or-death scenario, but more of a child-friendly adventure.This is a game that I would solidly recommend you pick up on sale, particularly in the 50-75% off range. If you enjoyed Portal 1+2, you will enjoy this, just not nearly as much.

												I went into QC with 2 perspectives in mind: Tycho from PA's and Yahtzee's. 2 very contrasting opinions, and I had no idea which I'd side w/, b/c Yahtzee's complaints were very concerning: That I'd be able to break 2/3rds of the puzzles by simply stacking boxes, or the platforming would be a mess.Yahtzee's complaints were puzzling. I'm srsly & obnoxiously left wondering if he just isn't any good at this type of game, or, more likely, exaggerated to an extreme. I don't think I found a single puzzle where stacking boxes & breaking the system was my 1st guess, or where it was even possible. Then again, I didn't find the game partic. mind-bending as Tycho suggested, either; but it was totally satisfying.I'm mixed on de Lancie's VA work. I love Q, & I love de Lancie as Q, but when he speaks in this game I'm picturing Q when I want to picture the mustachio'd madman of SCIENCE! It's...distracting.Level design is p. exquisite. QC ain't Portal, but it's a great supplement. Recommended.

Posted: January 21, 2013
												A good bit of fun that I got for 1.50 on a Steam sale. It's quite short and not TOO challenging, but the design is really tight and at that price point one can hardly complain. Some of the sections rely on some pretty deft dimension swaps, which I'm not sure I always cared for, but deaths are minor and don't really upset the game's flow. The game really relies on a few underlying principles and then gradually introduces more complexity. What's nice is it felt like there were multiple solutions to each room, which made it more exciting to experiment. The story is told Portal-style and is mainly just a cute aside to bridge together the puzzles. It's intended to be quite kid-friendly so don't expect much depth in that department. Not everything needs to be a grand epic though and, while it's not going to produce big laughs, the voice of John de Lancie will still put a smile on your face. Good stuff.

Posted: July 10, 2012
												I'm going to copy my opinion from QUBE, but it is essentially Portal 2 with better puzzles, and a weaker storyline.  Is this a bad thing?  Hellz no!  The alternate dimensions and some of the puzzle qualities that you can do with them (IE have all four dimensions available, but can only hold two at a time) make you have to do some serious thinking and planning to work out well.  This is much better than Portal, because your hand isn't held nearly as much through the game - if you are taking too long to complete it though, you will get audio with a subtle hint, which is nice.Much like QUBE though, there are some wonky physics in it.  One puzzles was especially frustrating because of it, but nothing in this game is a dealbreaker.  For a game that's as long as Portal 2 at only $15, it's a fantastic deal for fans of the genre.

Posted: June 24, 2012
												Everyone wants to compare this to Portal, but other than the fact that it's a puzzle game with a narrative, I really don't see that.  But then, maybe they just haven't played many of those games?At any rate, you gain power over the different dimensions as you go along, and are forced to use them to navigate a bunch of contrived scenarios.Unlike Portal, the story doesn't do a good job of explaining *why* each room is the way it is.  It explains the damage, but not the rest of the layout.But it doesn't matter.  The narrative is just there to entertain you while you solve puzzles.  Said puzzles start out extremely easy and don't ramp up in difficulty until about halfway through the game, where they suddenly get quite a bit harder...  And they stay that difficulty through the rest of the game.They tried to give it replay value by having collectables and setting time and dimension-shift goals for you to meet, but but they're completely artificial and I never feel like doing those.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												I have a love-hate relationship with this game.It's a great game and great concept, and the puzzles are well thought out.  Most of the time it's fairly obvious what you're supposed to do to pass a level.  Unfortunately, the game requires good timing and ninja like jumping from platform to platform.  If you're the sort who rage quits after the third time of missing a jump and having to restart from the last checkpoint, you'll hate this game.  I don't normally enjoy games that require that sort of exactness, but Quantum Conundrum is apparently my exception.  I'll put up with the annoyances of missed jumps, although sometimes I have to stop playing and take a break before coming back to the level.This is a game my ten year old daughter and I play together, and often when she realizes what we have to do to pass a level she shakes her head and says, "Daddy, don't you dare!"  We go ahead and do it anyway, and have a great time with it.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												So if you like action puzzles with a side of comedy (like Portal), then you'll love this.With that said there are some frustrations. Starting off small, there isn't a quit game or log out button. *SAO Panic mode*But the real issue I've had so far is that if your computer isn't up to par, don't bother. I have a decent computer, runs most games pretty well. This one was on the far end of what my computer can handle, but I dont entirely mind it being a little slow. For whatever reason though, if you have low fps, it jacks with the physics of the game, and damn near breaks some the puzzles. For example, in a Stairway to Fluffy, it supposed to set up safes in four nice stacks, but my last stack would always fall over no matter what I tried. Wondering what was wrong I checked up on some forum and found that if your fps is to low then they won't stack properly, and to fix it you had to look away from it, but then it makes it super difficult to be able to turn back around and time the laser to make the stairs.In a couple more puzzles, the low frame rates causes the little bird thing (forgot it's name) to not hold down a button long enough to activate a laser. I spent about 15 minutes wondering what I was missing when I realized that when I looked away something haad been activated.I've only been playing this game for an hour, so I can't imagine how many other game breaking malfunctions this puzzle game is going to have due to low fps, but I don't know if I can take it anymore. And it's not like there's a graphics setting that I could lower.But if you have nicer hardware, good for you. Get this game and tell me how it is.

Posted: July 19, 2015
												Good physics/platforming puzzle game. The main mechanic is that you can switch to 4 special "dimensions" to alter the physics, e.g. you can make all objects lighter so you can pick them up. In many levels you have to put a heavy object on a button to open a door. There is also a lot of timing and precise platforming, especially later on. The puzzles themselves are clever, but not super difficult. After figuring out what's going on in a level, you still need to make a plan and execute that plan, which is what takes the most time. The narration of the crazy professor (which seems to be aimed at 8 year olds), humanoid robots that make weird faces and the professor's pet give the game a very unserious feel. There is not much of a story. The collectibles are nice. You can replay individual levels and try to finish in a given time, without using the checkpoints and within a limited number of dimension shifts. These goals are pretty difficult and require a lot of attempts. 12 levels are sold separarely as two DLCs.Overall, it's an enjoyable game if you like physics/platforming/timing and don't mind the childishness.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												If you liked the Portal games,  definitely check this one out. Since people are bound to compare to the portal games I'll lay some stuff out.1. The main mechanic is shifting between 4 different dimensions to solve puzzles. This was almost as fun as thinking with portals.2. In the game, your uncle talks while you solve puzzles. Big drawback: he's not very entertaining. At all. Seriously, this was just terrible writing. Only slightly better than complete silence.3. You're required to do some platforming at some parts. I've read about some people getting aneurysms over this, and while I never had too much trouble making jumps, I can see why people would gripe. Other things:+ I really did like the cartoony art style.+ The barfing cloning devices and cat that follows you around were always welcome sights.- Level design was just lazy. When going between rooms, you'll pass clones of the same corridors over and over.- In the last third of the game, there were maybe 2 or 3 areas that I'm sure plenty of people will get annoyed over. Not because they're hard to figure out, but tough to execute.This game will exercise your brain with puzzles that are not too challenging but definitely fun. It's not the perfection that Portal 2 is, but it'll help scratch that puzzle itch.8.5/10

Posted: May 23, 2015
												5/10, wouldn't recommend, but not because it is bad, there are just much better alternatives.I've completed this games story, and I have no desire to go back for challenge modes (all the same maps) or to find the "collectibles".  The reasons I bought and finished this game are all repeated ad-infinitum, and never expanded.   the "lens flare" effect in some of the dimensions is awful, sometimes leading me to not be able to see a thing, and I have my contrast set pretty low.  The ending is thoroughly disappointing.the biggest complaint though is that this game tries so hard to be Portal, rather than just being itself.  the last 10% of the game especially.  nearly every single moment took me back to "yea but Portal did this better"  and a game shouldn't be like that, it shouldn't constantly remind me of something else that I played, it just feels like a cheap rip-off, and makes me think the writers/developers lack any creativity, which they clearly didn't for the first 25% of the game!  it felt like "well that was a fun conclusion to that game, lets do it too!" rather than "this is who our villain is, this is who our mentor is, and this is who our player character is, what would they do, and how would they interact in our story"In conclusion; the game had its own [good] things going, but someone decided that Portal was a huge hit, so lets just borrow the end of that game and call it our own, who cares about the awesome characters we developed, who cares if it makes the narorator/mentor sound bi-polar, who cares... they liked portal!

Posted: December 31, 2014
												It took me far too long to play this game through. I pre-ordered it way back when and, like many other games in my Library, inexplicably stopped after playing a good chunk. Only in the last few days of 2014 did I finally get back to it and complete the last 2/3rds, and I'm sad it took me so long to finish this wonderful game.Shortly after your mother drops you off to visit your uncle (Professor Quadrangle, voiced by John de Lancie who narrates the game in a GLaDOS-like manner), you find that an incident has placed him in some sort of strange pocket dimension and cut off power to his mansion. Using one of his latest inventions, the Inter-Dimensional Shift device (IDS), you push through puzzles to power the place back up utilizing four different dimensions in which the properties of time, matter, and gravity are changed. These dimensions are unlocked as you progress, and can only be utilized when the corresponding battery is in the room. The batteries won't always be plugged in either, meaning sometimes you'll have to retrieve them from another part of the room before you can go forward.I'm not a huge puzzle master, and I'm pretty sure more than once I "solved" a puzzle in a way that wasn't meant to happen, but I never found myself hopelessly stuck; it was always just a matter of trying a couple different things until something worked, or knowing what I had to do but having to get it right. The puzzle difficulty felt perfect, hard enough that it felt good to solve and wasn't a boring pushover, but not too hard where I could spend half an hour desperately trying to figure things out. Every time a dimension is added to your roster there's a puzzle or two to help you get the hang of what it does and how it works. I suppose if you're a puzzle master, however, it might seem like child's play.Through the narration of John de Lancie and a beautiful soundtrack there's never a dull moment...not that things can get very dull when you're flying through the air on a coffee table. I was pleasantly surprised to find that I had already purchased the soundtrack...and all the DLC! I don't remember doing that, hm.I'm a little upset at how many negative reviews are on the front page, but I suppose you can't please everyone. The ending WAS lackluster, though maybe it's resolved in some way in the DLC. Many people seem to hate the narration and the physics engine too, but I didn't have a problem with either. In fact I very much enjoyed the constant voice acting, and didn't find it annoying in the slightest. I guess I just really like John de Lancie's voice.Overall I must recommend it. It's cute, it's fun, it's silly.

Posted: June 7, 2015
												I wish I could give this game a positive review I really do, but I can't. I loved portal and in many ways this game attempts to be similar with physics based puzzles that you are required to solve in order to get to the exit for each room, and with the added twist that you can shift dimentions to either make all the objects fluffy and light so they can be carried or blown by fans, or extra heavy so they're impervious to lasers, or can activate pressure switches, or another dimention where time runs really slowly allowing to you throw objects and catch them further ahead.  But a number of things let these brilliant gameplay idea down.1) Motion sickness. I play FPS games every day and NEVER have a problem with motion sickness except when playing this game. No matter what FOV I set the game to within 15-20 minutes I have to turn the game off as I am feeling sick and dizzy, I have no idea what this game is doing differently from all the rest, but it is truly dreadful.2) Precision platforming in first person. Throughout the game you are required to jump from safe object to safe object in order to solve some problems, the problem is the controls are so impresise, you can't see your feet and you move as if you're on an ice rink. It's enough to drive a sane person crazy trying to judge your jumps, and in quite a few puzzles if you miss your jump you have to start the puzzle again, some of which require quite a bit of setup before hand.3) Despite having John De Lancie as the voice of the narrator the "witty" dialogue is just not witty or funny at all, it just falls completely flat and becomes more annoying the further you get into the game.4) There is very little variety in the design of the rooms and objects, after you've got about 30-60 minutes into the game you've pretty much seen everything you're going to see (with a few random room exceptions), and everything starts to look very samey.Well I've just has another fruitless 20 minutes unsuccessfully trying to jump between 5 safes all in a row and falling off one of them each time, or failing at the final jump to the exit, and yet again I feel dizzy and like I am going to throw up. Call me picky but that's not the kind of feeling I want to have after playing a game.

Posted: July 10, 2012
												I'm going to copy my opinion from QUBE, but it is essentially Portal 2 with better puzzles, and a weaker storyline.  Is this a bad thing?  Hellz no!  The alternate dimensions and some of the puzzle qualities that you can do with them (IE have all four dimensions available, but can only hold two at a time) make you have to do some serious thinking and planning to work out well.  This is much better than Portal, because your hand isn't held nearly as much through the game - if you are taking too long to complete it though, you will get audio with a subtle hint, which is nice.Much like QUBE though, there are some wonky physics in it.  One puzzles was especially frustrating because of it, but nothing in this game is a dealbreaker.  For a game that's as long as Portal 2 at only $15, it's a fantastic deal for fans of the genre.

Posted: June 24, 2012
												Everyone wants to compare this to Portal, but other than the fact that it's a puzzle game with a narrative, I really don't see that.  But then, maybe they just haven't played many of those games?At any rate, you gain power over the different dimensions as you go along, and are forced to use them to navigate a bunch of contrived scenarios.Unlike Portal, the story doesn't do a good job of explaining *why* each room is the way it is.  It explains the damage, but not the rest of the layout.But it doesn't matter.  The narrative is just there to entertain you while you solve puzzles.  Said puzzles start out extremely easy and don't ramp up in difficulty until about halfway through the game, where they suddenly get quite a bit harder...  And they stay that difficulty through the rest of the game.They tried to give it replay value by having collectables and setting time and dimension-shift goals for you to meet, but but they're completely artificial and I never feel like doing those.

Posted: February 28, 2015
												I was looking forward for this game when I knew that Kim Swift, involved in the development of Valve's Portal, worked on this game too. It seemed whimsical and fun.Unfortunately it actually feels empty and flat. It's like a compilation of discarded gameplay ideas for Portal. Fun, sure enough, but detachted from meaning or context. I was expecting greater character interaction than portal had (judging by the cover), but Ike just stands there on some levels and does nothing but look angry from time to time. The end of the game is a complete letdown: the guy on the cover (the player's uncle) isn't ever seen but as a silluette at the very end. Paintings of his ancestors on the walls give more interaction than him. The final "boss" fight is too easy too.The humour might be the best part of this game. The way how things, like the paintings change when you use the special powers, the backstory given for all the characters and how they made fun of popular book titles to fit particle physics somehow is all very well thought out.Summing up, It's a fun game but not one you'd like to repeat. DAMN YOU SQUARE ENIX!

Posted: August 7, 2014
												I was looking for a Portal-like puzzle fix when a friend recommended QC.Strange Facility: YesOdd narrator/overseer: Yes (John DeLancie!)Odd "Support" Character: YesPuzzles: Yes and YesItem Hunt: YesLow Stress: Yes (time trials are an optional pain)Humorous and colorful, QC is a fun puzzle-platformer game. It is more casual in nature than Portal. Things can get quite Heavy (or Fluffy) at times. Keyboard-mouse works fine, though I did resort to a mouse side-button for really quick activation of an ability. There's also two DLC for more fun. Enjoy! Overdue Update: DLC weren't as fun as expected. No plot or narrator, only challenging puzzles. I'll admit that I didn't get very far, but I didn't feel the same atmosphere that I enjoyed in the main game. If you're looking for challenge, the DLC might be worthwhile. Myself, I've found some Portal fan-creations for my time.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is a tough game to review. I want to like it more than I do, it's full of charm, but the puzzles just aren't that interesting as I'd like. There is less variety than I would like, and as other reviewers have stated, instead of having all the powers at your fingertips all of the time, the game gives you only what you need.While this can be good to make it easier, it also causes it to be a bit of hand holding, not letting people try to solve the puzzles with everything at their disposal. It's also takes more skill than actual puzzle solving ability. Sometimes I'm just freakin' lost because I have to time things just right to work, and it's harder than it looks.The narrator, John de Lancie (Plays Q in Star Trek: The Next Generation) does a great job with a lot of humorous commentary.I do recommend this game. It's a good game. Maybe not Portal quality, but certainly a worthy effort. 7/10

Posted: December 16, 2015
												What can I say? It's a fun first person puzzle game, and having John de Lancie (Q from Star Trek: The Next Generation) provide his voice made it so much better. There are a lot of parallels to Portal but that is because this game was made by Kim Swift who made Portal. She even came up with the idea for Quantum Conundrum while she was working on Portal. The puzzles themselves are challenging but not frustratingly so. They are physics based and it can take a few tries to get them to behave the way you want them to. There are also plenty of hidden collectables throughout the game, so you completionists out there can get your fix. One of the downsides is that it was a little short, about six, seven hours to beat (I wasn't doing a collectable run). Overall it was fun, witty, and callenging, everything I look for in a game.9/10 would science again.

												I started off really liking this. It woudl rank 4th in terms of puzzlers for me. After the Portal Series and The Talos Principle Series and aso behind Magrunner. The problem is the physics, or rather my frustration at spending way to much time retrying the jumps that lead to death if you mistime them or misjudge the distances etc which is very easy to do. I enjoy working out the solutions  but I don't want to spend my evenings with repeated jump/death/retry. Also the save points aren't very clear and it's frustrating to have to go back and rework a section you have already completed. I got quite a long way through and then just lost enthusiasm. I woudl still recommend people give it a try as long as you're very good at jumping when the physics is uncertain.

Posted: June 23, 2012
												When a game forces you to realize that you have to time jumps in adherence to the different temporal states and velocities without making you realize its making you think that? When it's done in a colourful, soothing, and slightly dark tounge-in-cheek way? Thats downright delicious. My surprise at who the companion voice actor to this game turned out being was the wry-voiced cherry on top. Posted: June 24, 2012
												Pretty fun game. The dialogue and story were interesting and humorous. There were some cool puzzles, and a few of them were fairly complex to understand or coordinate. This game has heavy platforming and quick-reflex challenges, which make up most of the difficulty in many of the stages (rather than complex puzzle solving). Quick reflexes aren't necessarily required for the platforming, they're mainly needed for switching between dimensions. The majority of the complicated platforming parts actually happen in the slow motion dimension.Unfortunately, as with most other games in the genre, this one is pretty short. I completed it in under 5 hours despite failing repeatedly on a few of the puzzles, in addition to taking my time to absorb the somewhat-skippable story. I would have liked to see another hour or two with some more puzzles that were mentally challenging rather than reflex-based.Recommendation: Buy it if you love the genre or if it's on sale.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Quantum Conundrum, while fun at first, felt like one of the longest games I've ever played. Maybe that was a result of the fun quickly turning to boredom, or the lack of any semblence of a story, or something else I'm not picking up on, the result is the same: Tedium. If you can grab this game for under $5 during a sale, I'd recommend it purely for John De Lancie's (Q from Star Trek TNG) voice acting and some of the cute puzzles, but there's not enough variety here to make you feel like you've accomplished something every time you clear a room. Instead of saying "Oh THAT was cool!" you're more likely to say "Well thank christ that's over". Some of the later puzzles are also not very well thought out and require bending of the game's rules to complete. Instead of providing a solution within the parameters of the game, I had to avoid those parameters, or bend them, to get through the last leg of the game. And to think, Kim Swift quit her job at Valve to work on THIS. I can't recommend it.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Made by some of the people who did Portal, going into it this game with very little knowledge of it, I could feel the Portal like elements seeping through the screen as I played along. Even the puzzles make you use the same parts of your brain that you do when playing Portal. It also caused me to feel the same type of brain melting numbness I got when I played Portal. But don't let this turn you off it and think it's a Portal clone. Far from it my friend. Sure you have a quirky overlord (in this  case your uncle) giving you helpful, and not so helpful comments along your puzzle building road, along with, as I said before, the puzzles feeling similar, but thats where it ends. My main love for this game goes to the incredible voice actor, John DeLancie, who perfectly portrays your uncle who's not at all keen to have you in the house putting back together the pieces while he's stuck in this empty non-existential dimension that contains blackness (according to him anywway). It may have been because I'm older but I liked the puzzles in this game. It had that good balance of difficulty but not too much that it makes you rage quit (although I did once or twice have to look up on YouTube for a solution - some of the puzzles are hard!) With that said, I do recommend this game. It helps wake up your brain and is a good little brain worker for those than enjoy puzzles (like I do)

Posted: November 10, 2012
												Quantum Conundrum gives a Portal vibe in its mechanics, puzzles, use of cubes, and narrator (I'd argue the uncle is on-par or better than GLaDOS)...probably because Kim Swift, the lead designer of Portal, directed it. The game is great with building on previously-learned material, giving you a new power, then repeating. And the new powers are fun to play around with (there were many instances where I probably did something I wasn't supposed to). The uncle's monologues and the death screens provide excellent comedy. Very difficult time attack/least shifts used/no death runs for that added challenge are there when you finish the game. If you liked Portal (or Q.U.B.E.) or just like puzzles and you're looking for something new and zany, this game is definitely for you!

Posted: January 21, 2013
												A good bit of fun that I got for 1.50 on a Steam sale. It's quite short and not TOO challenging, but the design is really tight and at that price point one can hardly complain. Some of the sections rely on some pretty deft dimension swaps, which I'm not sure I always cared for, but deaths are minor and don't really upset the game's flow. The game really relies on a few underlying principles and then gradually introduces more complexity. What's nice is it felt like there were multiple solutions to each room, which made it more exciting to experiment. The story is told Portal-style and is mainly just a cute aside to bridge together the puzzles. It's intended to be quite kid-friendly so don't expect much depth in that department. Not everything needs to be a grand epic though and, while it's not going to produce big laughs, the voice of John de Lancie will still put a smile on your face. Good stuff.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												A lot of people are going to compare this game to Portal based on the overall design and style of the game. Unfortunately, that is an extremely narrow point of view and completely negates many of the inventive pieces that are brought into a game like Quantum Conundrum. While its fairly obvious that QC is influenced by Portal (should that really be any surprise considering the individuals behind both games), you are forced into solving puzzles and performing FPS platforming in a way that was never introduced into the Portal series. This creates a unique game experience which has you thinking the whole way through. Admittedly, puzzles aren't as challenging as one might expect, but there is enough quality levels in the base game to keep you occupied for several hours. At a budget price, it's a pretty easy sell and with the prospect of new levels and support coming down the pipe, this looks to be a fun series to help support.

												Some peoples say: if you like Portal then you like this game. Not really. First and most important - different puzzle "complete mechanism". What i mean: in Portal (at least in Portal 2) you need figure, how this puzzle must be solved (main time) and then solve puzzle for a minute; in QC you figure how this puzzle must be solved for a minute and then must do some keyboards ninja tricks (quite frequently difficult and annoying). So, you often facing with a situation, when you straight know how puzzle must be solved, but can't done it, because not so fast and not in the order press keys. Posted: December 30, 2012
												Good: Puzzles are fun and rarely frustrating, with more emphasis on platforming skill and timing than the very similar Portal. Voice acting is perfect and writing is often funny. Very pretty with consistently interesting design. Gameplay manages to have a distinctly fresh feel -- switching between dimensions works flawlessly. Bad: Puzzles occasionally require a consistency that the (decently realistic) physics engine cannot support, leading to struggling with mechanics rather than brain-teasers. One or two puzzles require application of techniques that are not well indicated/taught. Entire hallways frequently copy-pasted exactly. Gamepad controls increase difficulty ten-fold ("what do you mean I can't look and activate a button simulatenously"), and menu support is spotty at best.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Quantum Conundrum provides a nice first person physics puzzler to interest people. The gameplay consists of picking up and moving or throwing objects along with changing physics through 4 different dimensions. Along the way are various contraptions that are used in combination with each dimension and platforming elements. Most levels have simple puzzles and platforming, but there are some tricky ones to give a challenge now and then. The story is simple, but features Professor Quadwrangle, a strange and funny scientist voiced by John de Lancie, and his nephew. He provides humor and hints in the game along with some ancedotes and storytelling. The game is cartoony, with big open spaces and giant sized objects perfect for platforming. This fits the style of gameplay right and explains the strangeness of some inventions easily. The music compliments the eccentricity of the manor's set of rooms. For its quirkyness and humor, Quantum Conundrum is a fun and funny first person puzzle game.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Did I buy this for Tim Curry voiceacting goodness? Hells yes I did! And I was not disappointed! The difficulty  was a smooth curve overall, the graphics delightful, and the humour enjoyably tongue-in-cheek.  I'm not going to discount the annoyance of the rail sections, or the bizarre stuttering that happened as it loaded new areas (seriously game, what the heck?), or the artifical difficulty in some of the later puzzles. Overall a fun way to spend a few afternoons, but I don't reccomend playing more than two hours at a time.

Posted: June 21, 2012
												As of this writing, I'm only ~25% in, but I honestly feel that's enough to write a recommendation for this.Think Portal, but without Thinking With Portals and instead thinking with Interdimensional Travel. Without a psychopathic AI nagging you, there's a potentially psychopathic family member, voiced by none other than John De Lancie, who provides just as much amusement as GLaDOS does.Drawing comparisons between this and Portal is pretty much the best way to describe it. It's a puzzler with moving things around and physics based puzzles that relate to the current properties of a material. Want something heavy? Lightweight? In slow motion? There's a dimension to solve that puzzle there.I'm playing with slightly bad framerate so the jumps are a little trickier for me, but it's something ignorable to the rest of the gameplay.Brilliant, and I strongly recommend you put down anything nonimportant / nonessential and buy this and play - right now.

Posted: June 24, 2012
												Pretty fun game. The dialogue and story were interesting and humorous. There were some cool puzzles, and a few of them were fairly complex to understand or coordinate. This game has heavy platforming and quick-reflex challenges, which make up most of the difficulty in many of the stages (rather than complex puzzle solving). Quick reflexes aren't necessarily required for the platforming, they're mainly needed for switching between dimensions. The majority of the complicated platforming parts actually happen in the slow motion dimension.Unfortunately, as with most other games in the genre, this one is pretty short. I completed it in under 5 hours despite failing repeatedly on a few of the puzzles, in addition to taking my time to absorb the somewhat-skippable story. I would have liked to see another hour or two with some more puzzles that were mentally challenging rather than reflex-based.Recommendation: Buy it if you love the genre or if it's on sale.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												Quantum Conundrum is a 3D puzzle game which tries to be quirky, but unfortunately isn't quite there. The game was obviously inspired by portal in many ways - while the fundamental gameplay elements are very different from Portal, in the end it is by and large a 3D puzzle/environment navigation game where you have the ability to mess with the environment and thus make your way through it. Your uncle is the faceless voice which guides you through the game, but he is no GLADOS, and the game as a whole just feels like an excuse to solve a bunch of physics puzzles which are okay but ultimately not amazing.It isn't a terrible game, and you could do worse with puzzle games, but it is no Portal, and it definitely was trying to be. While the switching between various environmental effects - reversed gravity, super heavy objects, super light objects, and slow - is interesting at times and allows for some interesting effects, on the whole the game isn't incredible and you aren't made the less by not having experienced it. It isn't a waste of time, but you could spend that time better on things which are more interesting.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Quantum Conundrum, while fun at first, felt like one of the longest games I've ever played. Maybe that was a result of the fun quickly turning to boredom, or the lack of any semblence of a story, or something else I'm not picking up on, the result is the same: Tedium. If you can grab this game for under $5 during a sale, I'd recommend it purely for John De Lancie's (Q from Star Trek TNG) voice acting and some of the cute puzzles, but there's not enough variety here to make you feel like you've accomplished something every time you clear a room. Instead of saying "Oh THAT was cool!" you're more likely to say "Well thank christ that's over". Some of the later puzzles are also not very well thought out and require bending of the game's rules to complete. Instead of providing a solution within the parameters of the game, I had to avoid those parameters, or bend them, to get through the last leg of the game. And to think, Kim Swift quit her job at Valve to work on THIS. I can't recommend it.

Posted: April 2, 2013
												I am inevitably going to draw comparisons to Portal for any first person puzzle game especially one for which cubes play such an integral part. You don't have a portal gun but an IDS device, no that's not an Iain Duncan Smith device that makes your pensions and benefits disappear but an Inter-Dimensional Shift device to flip between dimensions that give items different properties. A great puzzle game, like Portal, makes you feel clever when you solve a problem but a bad one will frustrate you and make you feel like an idiot. This game does a pretty good job, it is not as satisfying as Portal but it is still good fun. Some of the puzzles require precise timing and can take a number of attempts but do not get too frustrating. John de Lancie does a great job voicing the professor that adds an interesting plot to ties the puzzles together. The game is a good length. The locations designs are somewhat repetitive but all in all this is a good game just not as good as Portal.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												I've read through some of the reviews written, and it seems like the main complaint is that this game is too much of a platformer and not the puzzle game some people expected it to be. I however enjoyed the platforming as much as, if not more than the puzzling. In the beginning, the game does come out as more of a puzzle game, but that changes as you progress further into the game. The difficulty of the game wasn't too hard for me, so I never really experienced that feeling of ragequitting which some people explained in their reviews that they felt, but later on in the game and especially during the DLCs the game requires a bit of thinking and some exploring aswell to help you figure out what to do to advance. The story was alright although it didn't wow me. Also it felt a bit like it was an afterthought rather than being thought through. It felt like the game's ending left an opening for a sequel, which would be interesting to see, and which I personally would probably purchase.I really liked the characters and the fact that the uncle interacts a lot during levels, but also between and tells stories about the different paintings in the manor. Although I did not feel like Ike contributed to the game as much as I'd hope he would. If a sequel does come out, I hope that Ike interacts and maybe even helps a lot more than he did in this game.I bought the game and the DLCs during sales, but I feel that the original price of the game is pretty fair and worth it. I do not feel like the DLCs are worth the original price, since I kind of forced myself through them more than wanting to finish them. There is no interaction with any other character at all during the DLCs so you're all alone during all the 5 or 6 stages of each DLC. All-in-all I do recommend the game, even more when it's on sale.

Posted: June 23, 2012
												Quantum Conundrum tries a little too hard to live up to Portal, and falls just a little too short. The mechanics are fun, but they're rarely used in interesting ways. Posted: December 25, 2012
												pros: innovative puzzle mechanics (consisting of fluffy, heavy, slow, and reverse dimensions that can alter physics and objects in the level), stats and collectibles are available for completionists, enjoyable soundtrack, and an art style that gives this game a unique aesthetic.cons: platforming can be tedious, some lag spike issues, better dialogue is desired - because the main voice tells dry jokes constantly and gives hints to a puzzle when you don't want hints. And there is a level near the end where you have to stack 15 boxes to get to a higher ledge... some level designs are definitely questionable. You also can't quick save/save slot, there is an automatic checkpoint save but you can't even load that file, so when you leave the game you have to start from the very beginning of the chapter.Overall, most of the early puzzles are easy and I did find a few that were challenging, some level designs could of been improved, and the single player campaign takes around 5-6 hours. Quantum Conundrum season pass comes with additional DLC missions (reviews on the comments) and a soundtrack folder.  And for those who didn't know, this game was directed by Kim Swift (ex-Valve employee,  designer of Portal).The base game has my recommendation.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												(I had a previous review but i don't think it posted so i'll try again)Well, I finished the game. I have to say, it was very interesting to go through. I enjoyed it for many reasons, but many others don't for the same reasons. Some people complained that it was a very slow and tedious to progress, but I thought it was very fun to have to figure out what you needed to do in order to finish the level. Many complained that getting all the new dimensions took to long, but i thought it was smart of them to add in the dimensions one at a time, making it so you understand the best way to use this dimension, instead of rushing through and never really learning the proper/best way. I agree that the puzzles weren't hard, but this game is pretty old. (Yes, 2012 is old for a game.) The puzzle industry around that time was growing, and this was a great game for it's time. The graphics were also really great, again considering that it was released 2012, and was up in the higher game quality. (Some games released at that year were Borderlands 2, Hotline Miami, Halo 4, Assassin's Creed 3, Mass Effect 3, Far Cry 3, MAX PAYNE 3, DIABLO 3, SOMETHING 3 JEEZ LOUIS COME UP WITH A DIFFRENT GAME ALREADY WE DON'T NEED 3 F*****G GAMES... Sorry lost my cool. :) I also agree that the ending was a little anti-climtic, making it kind of a bit hard to want to go back and get all the achivements, but none the less it was an ending that wrapped things up. Another thing would be that we never actually saw our uncle in real life, so that kind of ruined it for me too. Many people said the uncles jokes weren't really funny, but honestly, if you have a real uncle you know that all of their jokes are about as funny as your dad's. (WOOT WOOT just offended a couple orphans here! I am on FIRE!) However even though others complained that the jokes weren't good, i thought they were hilarious, maybe just my sense of humour. Another thing to was that he didn't pretend that you were dumb. Oh, that means it makes two metal thingys stick together reall well." He would go "The quaddrople x Semi- automatic fumpwraplle 3000 acts as a negative contrary triplled definied adhesive towarsd any anti-active semi-metals. I remeber the one time my friend made it, but spilled some on workshope table and a piece of metal he was working on, with his hand stuck in between! Oh my, he had a fun time explaining that to the paramedics!" Instead of dumbing it down for you, he simply made it easier for you to understand what happened or what it does.I think i'm nearing the end of my review now. I'm pretty sure I covered the bigger parts. I think this game would have been amazing if they had added in a world editor so you could build your own little puzzles, and steam workshop support. All in all I rate this game a good 9/10. not perfect but definitely something i would buy again if given the choice. When i read comments that normally sways my verdict if i should get this game or not. I don't want someone missing out on a game or getting a game and not liking it because of my rating. Decide for yourself if you want to get it or not, my rating should just be something that you read and go "Oh, He liked it. That's good for him." That's all!Edit: This isn't going to be short. I missed a couple things. I'll try to keep it shorter but i suck at that so... Anyways, people complained about the Physics engine not being very good. Posted: August 8, 2012
												I went into QC with 2 perspectives in mind: Tycho from PA's and Yahtzee's. 2 very contrasting opinions, and I had no idea which I'd side w/, b/c Yahtzee's complaints were very concerning: That I'd be able to break 2/3rds of the puzzles by simply stacking boxes, or the platforming would be a mess.Yahtzee's complaints were puzzling. I'm srsly & obnoxiously left wondering if he just isn't any good at this type of game, or, more likely, exaggerated to an extreme. I don't think I found a single puzzle where stacking boxes & breaking the system was my 1st guess, or where it was even possible. Then again, I didn't find the game partic. mind-bending as Tycho suggested, either; but it was totally satisfying.I'm mixed on de Lancie's VA work. I love Q, & I love de Lancie as Q, but when he speaks in this game I'm picturing Q when I want to picture the mustachio'd madman of SCIENCE! It's...distracting.Level design is p. exquisite. QC ain't Portal, but it's a great supplement. Recommended.

Posted: August 31, 2012
												From the brains behind the original Portal comes Quantum Conundrum. I am recommending the game for that fact alone. For those of you who have played Portal, this game roughly features the same premise. You play as a boy who wanders into his Uncle's "lab," gets a "gadget," and then you have to get from point A, to point B in order to "leave."For Portal lovers, there are little bits of of Portal-y goodness that shine through at times, but trust me, this is NOT Portal... and I mean that necessarily isn't a bad thing. The fact is, these characters (especially Ike) grow on you; and while they may not be GladOS level quality, there are some great script moments in the game. All in all, I guess what I'm trying to say is that, if you liked Portal at all, give this game a shot. Portal, it is NOT, but it's got a flavor all its own, and still gets a recommendation from me.

Posted: August 7, 2013
												The design for everything is like a Pixar film: bright, colourful and charming. The gameplay is a lot like Portal: easy to come to terms with but requiring out-of-box thinking at times.The plot -- or rather, speech -- you're constantly berated with is like a bad culmination of both: unending one-liners, bad puns, non-sequiters and dissenting jabs at your ability(s).You're treated to four different filters, or dimensions as they call it, that impact on the world around you: fluffy, heavy, slow and reverse. Naturally you can only use one at a time but require multiple in order to solve the puzzles before you. Transporting large objects, for example, requires that you make it light (fluffy), throw it, slow down time, run round obstacles, switch back to fluffy and catch it again. The ways the game has you using these different dimensions in unison may not be initially intuitive, but they certainly arent illogical.Its got that same wonder and feel to it that the original Portal did. I dont think the gameplay elements are strictly original, but the way it handles and presents them (much like its pseudo-ancestor) provides much satisfaction that it makes a rather hard thing to dislike. It perhaps skirts a little heavy on Portals tailcoat, but it'd be a wholly different thing if it didnt.You won't feel bad for playing it, but you may feel a little guilty for giggling at the portraits in the games when viewed from different dimensions.

Posted: November 10, 2012
												Quantum Conundrum gives a Portal vibe in its mechanics, puzzles, use of cubes, and narrator (I'd argue the uncle is on-par or better than GLaDOS)...probably because Kim Swift, the lead designer of Portal, directed it. The game is great with building on previously-learned material, giving you a new power, then repeating. And the new powers are fun to play around with (there were many instances where I probably did something I wasn't supposed to). The uncle's monologues and the death screens provide excellent comedy. Posted: July 3, 2012
												Where do I start? This is a fun puzzle game,  with puzzles being as hard as Portal 2's PeTI levels, although some of them are pretty easy to figure out once you get a hold of the game mechanics.Speaking of which, the ways that you use the five (yes, five, normal's a dimension if you hadn't noticed) dimensions are neat. Wanna lift a crate? Fluffy dimension. Need to weigh down something with a cardboard box? Heavy dimension. Do you want to fly across the room on a piece of furniture? A mixture of slow motion and reverse gravity oughta do the trick.There are some similarities between this game and Portal, some of which are obvious such as rooms of the mansion being like test chambers, the areas between said rooms involving chit-chat with someone speaking to you over the intercom and so on and so forth. The only thing that really separates this game from Portal is the difficulty curve, which spikes too high at times.TL;DR - Nice game. Some frustrating moments, but overall it's fine.

Posted: January 21, 2013
												A good bit of fun that I got for 1.50 on a Steam sale. It's quite short and not TOO challenging, but the design is really tight and at that price point one can hardly complain. Some of the sections rely on some pretty deft dimension swaps, which I'm not sure I always cared for, but deaths are minor and don't really upset the game's flow. The game really relies on a few underlying principles and then gradually introduces more complexity. What's nice is it felt like there were multiple solutions to each room, which made it more exciting to experiment. The story is told Portal-style and is mainly just a cute aside to bridge together the puzzles. It's intended to be quite kid-friendly so don't expect much depth in that department. Not everything needs to be a grand epic though and, while it's not going to produce big laughs, the voice of John de Lancie will still put a smile on your face. Good stuff.

Posted: October 3, 2013
												Quantum Conundrum - a game that sit somewhere in shadows of its more popular puzzle game brother - Portal. And while both of those video games are 3D puzzle games with platforming elements, the similarity really ends here. The concepts of the two franchises are different and I wish people would stop comparing them or claming that Portal will always be a better game without even playing Quantum Conundrum. If you're a fan of the genre, you will enjoy Quantum Conundrum even though it might be a bit too easy after playing other, similar titles. But, enough of that. It might be already clear, but I did enjoy Quantum Conundrum A LOT. And I probably enjoyed it a lot more than Portal 2. Yes, the story is pretty much a filler, it doesn't go anywhere and the ending is a set up for the sequel (which hopefully will happen although I doubt it...). Yes, the puzzles are mostly pretty easy and after getting tricky they still can be solved in under 30 minutes, But I still enjoyed my time with Quantum Conundrum...Its concept is interesting. The game gives the player the control over the enviroment instead of one particular thing (as with Portal and QUBE). It plays with physics letting you make elements weight more or less, slow the flow of time or even the entire gravity of the room. And it does so in unexpected ways such as makes you throw boxes so you can basically fly through the level using the gravity or lets you bounce on the platforms using a couch that you can make heavier and then lighter to fling yourself upwards. Those little mechanics that make the player say 'yeah, that clever' and then use those mechanics and mix them up in another level of the game. A concept of dimensions gives a bunch of possibilities for those mechanics and (again, hoping for it) there are a lot of paths that a sequel might take. The puzzles are never too hard. Something I dislike about puzzle games is the difficulty curve that gets really high after a while without letting the player understand what he should be doing. Quantum Conundrum teaches the player its mechanics and does a good job at it also bringing back things introduced in previous chapters in the later ones. The player never gets stuck for good or frustrated that he can't figure out a solution. The levels go by pretty fast and it gives the player the feeling of progress which, of course, pushes him forward through the game. I never felt like the game is too easy. It gave me a good challenge showing me what I can do and then mixing it up and making me do it. I never felt mad at the game for having some riddiculus solution for a puzzle. It wasn't complicated. It was always a simple concept. As for the story, well... I didn't really care too much for it and I don't think it is a bad thing either. The story was just there as a filler, the narration was okay and I see people really liking the professor. It just wasn't my thing, but it also didn't overshadow the gameplay. Everything is presented in a really lighthearted way, the graphics are bright and colorful and the overall game has a lot of character. So what about the negatives? There are negatives. As I've mentioned previously - the story is just a filler, it doesn't go anywhere and since the checkpoints bring you back to a set spot, you often have to listen to the same voice clip over and over again. The puzzles are simple, but not too simple and Portal veterans might breeze through the game. There are also corridors between levels that act as hidden loading screens and a "story time" kind of deal. Those get repeated pretty fast and they're mildly annoying. The fact that they are in fact just a window of time for the game to load the next map, also might result in a bit of a frame drop from time to time. Also, I should probably mention that Quantum Conundrum loves platforming a lot more than other 3D puzzle games. Something you should probably have in mind. Overall, I had a fantastic time with the game. It wasn't anything amazing, but it has a lot of potential and character to it and I wish we see a sequel one of these days.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												A lot of people are going to compare this game to Portal based on the overall design and style of the game. Unfortunately, that is an extremely narrow point of view and completely negates many of the inventive pieces that are brought into a game like Quantum Conundrum. While its fairly obvious that QC is influenced by Portal (should that really be any surprise considering the individuals behind both games), you are forced into solving puzzles and performing FPS platforming in a way that was never introduced into the Portal series. This creates a unique game experience which has you thinking the whole way through. Admittedly, puzzles aren't as challenging as one might expect, but there is enough quality levels in the base game to keep you occupied for several hours. At a budget price, it's a pretty easy sell and with the prospect of new levels and support coming down the pipe, this looks to be a fun series to help support.
